newsitem.title: USA: Ashland Coal coal costs decline in Q4.
newsitem.headline: Ashland Coal coal costs decline in Q4.

text.p: Ashland Coal Inc Tuesday reported its best quarterly results of 1996, citing reduced coal production costs.
And the company said it expects further cost improvements.
But fourth quarter profits of $9.4 million, or $0.50 per share on a fully diluted basis, still trailed the year earlier $11.6 million, or $0.61 per share.

Revenues for the fourth quarter were $152.1 million in 1996 and $169.2 million in 1995. Coal sales were 5.8 million tons in the fourth quarter of 1996 compared to 6.0 million tons in the same period in 1995.
"As expected, fourth quarter results improved substantially over the previous quarters of this year," commented chief executive William C. Payne.

"The cost of coal sold in the fourth quarter was a record low $22.51 per ton, $1 per ton lower than last year's fourth quarter. The operation of the dragline at Dal-Tex, which began in August of 1996, was the primary contributor to this improvement. "With the dragline, production at the Dal-Tex (mine complex in southern West Virginia) increased 19 percent and cost per ton decreased 17 percent from fourth quarter 1995 levels.

"We expect further improvements in per ton cost as a result of both the move of the Hobet 21 dragline across Mud River, which occurred earlier this month, and the completion of a $10.5 million overland conveyor extension at the same mine, which is expected in the third quarter," he said.
For the year, Ashland Coal earned $16.5 million, or $0.86 per share. In 1995, net was $41.4 million, or $2.16 per share.
Results throughout 1996 were adversely affected by the expiration of above-market contracts with CINergy Corp's Cincinnati Gas & Electric Co at the end of 1995, Ashland Coal said.

In addition to these contract, the fourth quarter comparison is affected by a reduction in employee benefit expenses related to a revision of an actuarial estimate and operating revenue related to the termination of a coal supply agreement, both recognized in the fourth quarter of 1995.

These two nonrecurring items added $2.1 million to income before tax in the fourth quarter of 1995 relative to the fourth quarter of 1996. Because of the effects of percentage depletion, however, a lower effective tax rate (which was negative) in the fourth quarter of 1996 more than offset the effect of the above two items.
